South-Central Interior Small Stream and Riparian
South-Central Interior Large Floodplain - Forest Modifier
aBWRWx-y6.memHandModelNotes:
medium to large streams.   Completely aquatic.

Even though this species is entirely aquatic, the original model had map units selected but a 0m exterior flowing water buffer. The 0m buffer essentially eliminates all map unit selections. In order to include areas such as stream banks, I changed the exterior buffer to 30m. I also made a similar change to the Gulf Coast Waterdog model. MJR 15 May 2009.

references.B89DUN01NAUS: Dundee, H. A., and D. A. Rossman. 1989. The amphibians and reptiles of Louisiana. Louisiana State Univ. Press, Baton Rouge.
references.B88ASH01NAUS: Ashton, R. E., Jr., and P. S. Ashton. 1988. Handbook of reptiles and amphibians of Florida. Part Three. The amphibians. Windward Publ. Co., Miami.
references.A01DUR01SEGP: Durflinger, M.C., C. Guyer, and M.A. Bailey. 2001. Distribution and population biology of the Black Warrior Waterdog, Necturus alabamensis. Southeastern Naturalist. 5(1), pp 69-84.
references.B59CAR01SEGP: Carr, A. and C.J. Goin. 1959. Guide to the reptiles, amphibians, and freshwater fishes of Florida. Gainesville, Univ. of Florida Press.
references.B95WIL01NCGP: Wilson, L. A. 1995. The Land Manager's Guide to the amphibians and reptiles of the South. Chapel Hill, NC: The Nature Conservancy.

habitat_description: The Alabama Waterdog is completely aquatic; inhabiting unpolluted medium to large streams with abundant shelter, rocky bottoms (Wilson).  They seem to prefer rivers and streams with logjams or other debris (Petranka) and are found around jams and tree roots (Ashton 1988).  They are found in streams greater than 10 feet wide (Dundee and Rossman 1989) and sand bottomed streams (Carr and Goin 1955).  Little is known of the waterdog’s life history.
